comments.commentBody: Yes, I and my cohort of fellow Stewart and Colbert watchers are in our 60s and 70s and even more. They're definitely not just a youth market!
Amen. So, for the upcoming election I shall mount my offensive by burying myself deep in the complete works of PG Wodehouse and Mark Twain, with R&R in Blues Brothers land.

Don't worry about Downton Abbey. With increasing inequities in wealth distribution and more and more power to corporate CEO's, the society you see in that TV series will soon be coming to a town near you. This nation,  that was once a society of opportunity is circling the drain!

So many of these items about Jon Stewart and The Daily Show emphasize the youth of the audience, which is indeed encouraging, but I'm on Medicare and I've been a Daily Show fan ever since I discovered it during the Dubya years. Now Letterman is leaving, Stewart is leaving, Stephen Colbert and Craig Ferguson are already gone--okay, I'll be watching Colbert when he replaces Dave, but he won't be the Colbert Report Colbert. I'm feeling like the occupants of Downton Abbey--things are changing too much, and not for the better!

No !  I was about to turn in for the night when I read this very sad and shocking news. First Bob Simon and now David Carr.  Two of the media's finest voices have been silenced by death's cold hand within a day of each other. Carr was among the very few columnists whom I always read and truly appreciated. My condolences to Carr's family, friends and co-workers at the NYTimes. He will be sorely missed.
Hey David. RIP! You'll be missed!

To lose the voice of David Carr, and to know that the Jon Stewart version of "The Daily Show" is going away, really alters and greatly diminishes intelligent criticism of the media. This is stunning, horrible news tonight. This whole week has been Friday the 13th for journalism

Dr. K,

The new chairman of the Ways and Means Committee is growing in stature every time he is mentioned in your blog or your column. He has a huge number of consultants and staff to generate lots of position papers.

The big challenge, is there anything that he can do to improve the lot of the American people & children, in time for the election? It should be easy for him to satisfy the major donors and cook up uncertainty about possible tax reform & entitlements to stir the Washington lobbyists but it will be extremely tough for him to improve the lot of the underemployed & part time workers who really have no future, or much opportunity.

He is young & may decide to break away from the donor pack and make a run for the White House in 2020, but I doubt it because he does not appear to have the intellectual arguments for making a case for what can be done to improve the well-being & opportunity for the majority of Americans,

A note on QE 1. It is my understanding that we would have had a catastrophic collapse of the US financial system & would have essentially dismantled the structure that made it possible to use QE2 to stabilize the economy & start the very long road back to recovery.

The austerians are still calling for a Balanced Budget Amendment.

Meanwhile the grand challenge of our time Global Warming goes addressed by our political leadership. Global warming is a perfect issue for giving American industry focus and it can pay investors handsomely.

David has been one of those unique voices to me over the years in which each time I see his byline, no matter the subject matter (...and he absolutely had an enviable wingspan...), his words wrap around me in compelling and unexpected ways. He had a fantastic, keen point of view and will be so deeply missed. Much love to the Carr's of this world.

...time to close the book on my late night fantasies of the return of the sweet spot...rest in peace my man.

First Bob Simon now Davis Carr?
My world just got a little more shaky.
It's always that way. Normal people go a little wonky when people they trust to tell the truth, suddenly leave the room, forever.
But I would like to mention I appreciated Carr was polite in a way many accomplished people, aren't.
This is a huge loss.

This is very sad; David Carr is gone far too soon.  David Carr was tops in whatever he did, as the Carpetbagger, and in writing more generally about media.  He was my favorite Times writer, in part because he had a sense of irony about things, including himself.  My condolences to his family.
Absolutely beautiful photograph of David by Chester Higgins. I will miss his reporting.  Thank you.

There are so few people who can look through the lense of their own lives enough to see the world for what it is, and with enough clarity and force to powerfully communicate that vision and wisdom, especially someone in a position to influence the Grey Lady. The New York Times will never be the same, and our country and our discourse will forever be diminished. My condolences to his family and those who loved him and shared their lives with his.
It's not at all lame to be thrilled to have been acknowledged by him.

I'm not even kidding...I've been tearing up upon hearing the news. Reading the tweets from journalists about @carr2n shows me I'm not alone. I know I'm not a journalist, nor did I actually know him, but I read his work avidly, read his tweets, loved his acerbic wit and felt a kinship to this person who felt so alive. I'll never forget the day he retweeted me (sounds lame, I know) because his persona shined through that medium. His engagement with followers & readers always felt as real and true as his writing and willingness to question the powers-that-be and status quo. I only wish he could continue to guide us into the future -- the "virtual" unknown.
He never failed us.

I just watched him commenting on journalism issues yesterday.  I always read his articles.  He was so insightful.  His book was inspirational and, I am sure, helped other people dealing with the scourge of drug addiction.  He will truly be missed.  We have lost two unique giants in the media world in two days.  Like a punch in the gut.  I am so sad.

Sorry, but you are flat-out wrong. They are marriages. The Windsor decision cemented this fact. Okay, you don't like it, but don't misstate the obvious. And don't go crying about how the Feds are taking away all powers of the states; you know this is also a lie. You're just frustrated because you can't prevent two people you don't even know from getting married. Get over it.
And CBT!
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy tends to work better than Freudian-style analysis, too. And it's designed to be short-term.

Enduring "talk therapy for years, even decades, to identify the source of pain" is a totally ineffective approach to psychotherapy and decades out of date. I hope the author will learn about trauma-informed therapy that includes some form of bodywork, especially as she say she has benefited from exercise for mood uplift. Focusing on the pain, on the why of the pain only feeds it and deepens the biologically-based negative bias of the untrained brain. Read Daniel Sielgel and Bessel van der Kolk, please!!!
What a huge loss.  I only discovered David and his wonderful writing after seeing Page One - he was the heart of that film. He'll be greatly missed.

For years, I was anxious and depressed, and tried various anti-depressants and anti-anxiety medications. Did not like the side effects and they tended to blunt my edge. I need my edge. I love my edge. My edge is part of what defines me. So I took a different approach. I divorced my abusive husband, moved to another state, and I haven't been happier or more at peace. Sometimes, the most obvious cure is the best. And I still have my edge.
Such a loss to journalism. The most media savvy critic-writer in our time.

Knew him, worked with him at the T.C. Reader back in the 1980's. David was on an ever upward trajectory, he was so good, in every way, he hit the mark, then he kept going.  Although his passing was way too soon, it somehow fits that it was at night, in a newsroom where his writing went full tilt, clackity clack, into the wee hours.  Oh, I will miss you.
What a shocker. My first read on a Monday was to read what Mr. Carr's insight was on the media. So sudden and sad.

@Phil 'Atmospheric geoengineering is a scam' It has never been tried, so how do you know? If temperatures should start to climb rapidly, wouldn't it be nice to have a technology which could stabilize things and buy time for a more permanent solution?

@Dale Tree planting is a nice, hippy-friendly way to remove CO2. Just one problem. Where do you plan to plant all these trees? If you try to plant them in the California desert, you will face an endangered species act lawsuit for wiping out the habitat of the Desert Tortoise. And where would you get the water from?

The thing is, trees aren't stupid. Most places where the soil and rainfall are suitable for trees, the trees have already found and colonized.
Beautifully written. I share your grief.

An anthem to China leading the world in internet development?! Wow, Bruce, the irony is apparently lost on you too.

I live in Shanghai and I'm only able to read this banned website by using a barely functional VPN (VPNs are routinely rendered unusable by the internet police).

And by the way, I have plenty of downtime to comment here today because I've once again been stuck at my desk trying unsuccessfully to upload several large media files to clients back in the US. Needless to say this is endlessly frustrating and unnecessarily bad for business

Oh yeah, I wanted to share the video with friends in China, so I uploaded it to Youkou. It failed the “audit and inspection” process: 已屏蔽，根据视听管理规定处理...A bad translation is "Shielded, treated according to audiovisual regulations"

Everybody sing along!

I think we are overreacting and putting our own twist on a good choral presentation.  I don't see it as an anthem to censorship at all, but a call for Chinese to lead the world in Internet development.  America is far behind many nations in our Internet development, and we should stop denigrating others -- who may be getting ahead of us.

I think it could be translated either way. Only the lyricists know the exact meaning. But, "Internet strengthens the country" is contrary to what the CCP's belief that internet threatens the country. That's why the increasing censoring over the internet.
